areas.title: Sun
areas.otherInfo: The Sun, which is the solar system's largest object, accounts for more than 99.86% of the mass of the solar system, and has an immense gravitational pull.

onClick.one: The Sun will burn for 130 million years, towards the end of this period it will grow large enough to consume Earth.
onClick.two: The Sun is the closest thing to a perfect sphere in the observed universe.
onClick.three: The Sun is classified as a yellow dwarf star.

areas.title: Mercury
areas.otherInfo: Mercury, the closest planet to the Sun is also the smallest of the 8 planets within the inner solar system.

onClick.one: A year on Mercury is 88 days, however a day on Mercury is 176 Earth days.
onClick.two: Even though it is closer to the Sun than Venus, it is actually cooler than Venus.
onClick.three: Mercury's magnetic field is about 1% the strength of Earth's.

areas.title: Venus
areas.otherInfo: Sometimes refered to as Earth's sister planet, Venus is the second planet from the Sun and bright enough to light up our night sky.

onClick.one: Because thier size and mass are simliar, sometimes Earth and Venus are referred to as sister planets.
onClick.two: With its slow rotation, a day on Venus is actually longer than a full year.
onClick.three: Venus is one of the few known planets that rotates clockwise on its axis.

areas.title: Earth
areas.otherInfo: Earth is the third planet from the Sun, our home is also the largest of the terrestrial planets.

onClick.one: Earth is the only plent that is not named after a god or goddess.
onClick.two: Because the rotation of our planet is slowing down, in 140 million years an average day would be 25 hours.
onClick.three: The lowest point on Earth, Challenger Deep, has a greater height difference than Mount Everest.

areas.title: Mars
areas.otherInfo: The fourth planet from the Sun and likely the first stop for human visitors, the Red Planet is spectacular in many fashions.

onClick.one: Theoretically, you could jump three times as high on Mars compared to Earth.
onClick.two: Less than half, 16 of 39, Mars missions have been sucessful.
onClick.three: Mars is home to the largest dust storms in the entire solar system, they can cover the planet for months.

areas.title: Astroid Belt & Others
areas.otherInfo: The asteroid belt roughly lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter, and marks the move from terrestrial planets to gaseous ones.

onClick.one: While scientists have confirmed hundreds of thousands of asteroids in the belt, there may be billions more.
onClick.two: The asteroid 1 Ceres is large enough to be a dwarf planet and is the largest astroid in the inner solar system.
onClick.three: Mining asteroids may be a critical enterprise within the next century.

areas.title: Jupiter
areas.otherInfo: Named after the King of Gods, Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest of all known planets in the solar system.

onClick.one: Jupiter is so large that 317 Earth masses would be needed for one Jupiter mass.
onClick.two: Ganymede, the largest of Jupiter's 67 moons, is even bigger than Mercury.
onClick.three: Because Jupiter rotates so quickly on its axis, each ~10 hours, it has the shortest day of all the planets.

areas.title: Saturn
areas.otherInfo: Saturn's rings capture our imaginations, and the sixth planet from the Sun is also the second largest.

onClick.one: Even at its distance, Saturn was large enough to be known by ancient civilizations.
onClick.two: The winds on Saturn are the fastest in the solar system, and reach up to 1,100 miles per hour (1,800km/hr).
onClick.three: Titan, one of Saturn's many moons, may have liquid methane lakes, and could be a harbor for life.

areas.title: Uranus
areas.otherInfo: The seventh planet from the Sun, Uranus, was not discovered until 1781.

onClick.one: Similar to Venus, Uranus rotates clockwise, the only two planets in the solar system to do so.
onClick.two: Because of it's chemical composition and pale blue color, Uranus is often referred to as the 'Ice Giant'.
onClick.three: Uranus is the coldest planet in our solar system, with a surface tempature of -371 F (-224 C).

areas.title: Neptune
areas.otherInfo: The furthest planet from the Sun is Neptune, the eighth and final planet in the solar system.

onClick.one: One orbit around the Sun for Neptune takes nearly 165 Earth years.
onClick.two: After Jupiter, Neptune has the solar system's second largest gravitation pull by a planet.
onClick.three: There has been only one spacecraft, Voyager 2, to have flown past Neptune.

areas.title: Kuiper Belt & Others
areas.otherInfo: The Kuiper Belt is a disk-shaped region in the outer solar system, it has many similarities to the asteroid belt, however is considerably larger.

onClick.one: The region is believed to contain hundreds of millions of small, icy bodies that are leftover from planet formation.
onClick.two: There are three dwarf planets known to exist in the Kuiper Belt, including Pluto, Haumea and Makemake.
onClick.three: In 2015, NASA sent the New Horizons spacecraft to survey Pluto, Charon and other objects in the belt.

areas.title: Planet X
areas.otherInfo: Also known as 'Planet Nine', if Planet X's discovery is confirmed, it may be 10 times the mass of Earth and orbit 20 times farther from the Sun than Neptune.

onClick.one: Given its distance from the Sun, it may take between 10,000 and 20,000 Earth years to make one full orbit around the Sun.
onClick.two: Planet X has not yet been fully discoverd, but mathematical modeling points to a high likelyhood of the planet's existance.
onClick.three: If proven to truly exist, Planet X would make up one of the most recent discoveries in astronomy, with scientists proposing its existance in 2015.

areas.title: Oort Cloud
areas.otherInfo: It is believed the Oort Cloud occupies the space somewhere between 2000 to 5000 AU from the Sun, 1 AU is about the distance from Earth to the Sun.

onClick.one: The Oort Cloud is so large that it is believed that it is affected by gravitational pull from other stars in the Milky Way Galaxy.
onClick.two: Some scientists believe that up to two trillion objects are within the Oort Cloud.
onClick.three: The Oort Cloud's outer limit is believed to define the edge of the Sun's gravitational dominance.
